(b) The Bank of Japan declares a decrease in its primary interest rate, verified by trusted financial news outlets.

Under these circumstances, the inquiry seeks to determine if Roger Federer will start on-court training as part of his rehabilitation process by July 31, 2024. Confirmation must be obtained from Federer, his coaching staff, or credible sports news sources, and the training must be included in his organized rehabilitation program. If there is no confirmation or it is reported that Federer has not started training by that date, the answer will be NO.

question.title: Will all of the following occur by July 31, 2024: (1) Paris announces a public transit-only policy for its 2024 Olympic venues, (2) The Bank of Japan announces a reduction in its key interest rate, and (3) Roger Federer resumes on-court drills as part of his rehab?

The announcement must be made through official channels (such as a press conference, official statement, or city government website) or reported by at least two major news outlets. The drills must be part of his structured rehabilitation program, not casual or personal activities. If no such confirmation is available by the resolution date, or if it is explicitly stated that Federer has not resumed drills by that time, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Is it guaranteed that the following will take place by July 31, 2024: (1) Paris implements a policy for its 2024 Olympic venues that allows access exclusively via public transport, (2) The Bank of Japan declares a cut in its main interest rate, and (3) Roger Federer begins practicing on the court as part of his rehabilitation?

The drills must be part of his formal rehabilitation program, not casual or personal activities. If no confirmation is available by the resolution date, or if it is explicitly stated that Federer has not resumed drills by that time, the outcome will be NO.

question.title: Will the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation announce new funding commitments totaling over $400 million by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation officially announces one or more new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million. The announcement(s) must be made through official Gates Foundation channels (such as their website or press releases) and be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not continuations of previously announced commitments. If no such announcement is made by the resolution date, or if the total of new funding commitments does not exceed $400 million, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Is it possible that the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation will declare new funding commitments exceeding $400 million by the end of July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if, by the date of July 31, 2024, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation makes an official declaration of one or more new funding commitments that sum to more than $400 million. The declarations must be issued through official channels of the Gates Foundation (such as their website or press releases) and must be covered by at least two credible news organizations (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments should represent new initiatives or substantial expansions of current programs, rather than extensions of previously announced commitments. If no such declaration occurs by the resolution date, or if the total of new funding commitments falls short of $400 million, the inquiry will conclude with a NO.

question.title: Given the Gates Foundation announces new funding commitments over $400 million by July 2024, will the ILO do the same?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: By July 31, 2024, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation officially announces one or more new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million. The announcement(s) must be made through official Gates Foundation channels (such as their website or press releases) and be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not continuations of previously announced commitments.

Then, will the International Labour Organization (ILO) announce new funding commitments totaling over $400 million by July 31, 2024? For the ILO, this resolves as YES if, by the same date, the ILO officially announces one or more new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million. The announcement(s) must be made through official ILO channels (such as their website or press releases) and be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not continuations of previously announced commitments.

para_P.title: If the Gates Foundation reveals new funding pledges exceeding $400 million by July 2024, will the ILO follow suit?
para_P.body:
Assuming the following is accurate: By July 31, 2024, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation makes an official announcement regarding one or more new funding pledges that in total surpass $400 million. These announcements must come through official channels of the Gates Foundation (such as their website or press releases) and be covered by at least two credible news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding pledges must consist of new projects or substantial enhancements of existing initiatives, not merely the continuation of previously declared commitments.

Then, will the International Labour Organization (ILO) declare new funding pledges that amount to over $400 million by July 31, 2024? For the ILO, this will be considered a YES if, by the same deadline, the ILO makes an official announcement regarding one or more new funding commitments that collectively exceed $400 million. These announcements must be made through official ILO channels (such as their website or press releases) and be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must consist of new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not just continuations of previously announced commitments.

question.title: Given both the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and the International Labour Organization announce new funding commitments totaling over $400 million each by July 2024, will Jerome Powell remain as Federal Reserve Chair through July 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: By July 31, 2024, both the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and the International Labour Organization officially announce new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million each. The announcements must be made through their official channels and reported by at least two reputable news sources. The commitments must be for new initiatives or significant expansions, not continuations of previous commitments. 

Given this, will Jerome Powell remain as the Chair of the Federal Reserve on July 31, 2024? Confirmation must come from official Federal Reserve announcements or be reported by at least two major news outlets. If he is no longer serving as Chair by that date for any reason, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: If both the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and the International Labour Organization declare new funding pledges exceeding $400 million each by July 2024, will Jerome Powell continue as Federal Reserve Chair until July 2024?
para_P.body:
Assuming the following holds true: By July 31, 2024, both the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and the International Labour Organization publicly reveal new funding pledges that together surpass $400 million each. These announcements must be made through their official communication channels and covered by a minimum of two credible news organizations. The pledges should be aimed at new projects or major expansions, rather than extensions of prior commitments. 

In light of this, will Jerome Powell still hold the position of Chair of the Federal Reserve on July 31, 2024? Verification must come from official communications from the Federal Reserve or be reported by at least two prominent news outlets. If he is not serving as Chair for any reason by that date, the answer to the question will be NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Both the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and the International Labour Organization announce new funding commitments totaling over $400 million each by July 2024, and (2) Jerome Powell remains as Federal Reserve Chair through July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, all of the following are true: (1) Both of the following occur: (a) The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation officially announces one or more new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million. The announcement(s) must be made through official Gates Foundation channels (such as their website or press releases) and be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not continuations of previously announced commitments. (b) The International Labour Organization officially announces one or more new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million. The announcement(s) must be made through official ILO channels (such as their website or press releases) and be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not continuations of previously announced commitments. If either organization does not make such an announcement by the resolution date, or if the total of new funding commitments does not exceed $400 million for either organization, the question resolves as NO. (2) Jerome Powell is still serving as the Chair of the Federal Reserve on July 31, 2024. Confirmation must come from official Federal Reserve announcements or be reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, CNBC, The Wall Street Journal, or Bloomberg). If he is no longer serving as Chair by the resolution date for any reason (including but not limited to resignation, removal, or end of term), the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, any interim or acting Chair appointments will not be considered as Powell remaining in the position.

para_P.title: Is it true that two conditions will be fulfilled: (1) The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and the International Labour Organization each declare new funding commitments exceeding $400 million by July 2024, and (2) Jerome Powell continues to hold the position of Federal Reserve Chair until July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if, by July 31, 2024, the following conditions are met: (1) Both of the subsequent events take place: (a) The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation makes an official declaration of one or more new funding commitments that total more than $400 million. These announcements must be disseminated through official Gates Foundation channels (like their website or press releases) and must be covered by at least two credible news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must represent new initiatives or substantial expansions of current programs, rather than extensions of previously disclosed commitments. (b) The International Labour Organization makes an official declaration of one or more new funding commitments that collectively exceed $400 million. These announcements must be made through official ILO channels (like their website or press releases) and must be reported by at least two reputable news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not continuations of previously announced commitments. If either organization fails to make such an announcement by the resolution date, or if the total of new funding commitments does not surpass $400 million for either organization, the inquiry will resolve as NO. (2) Jerome Powell must still be serving as the Chair of the Federal Reserve on July 31, 2024. This must be confirmed by official Federal Reserve announcements or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, CNBC, The Wall Street Journal, or Bloomberg). If he is no longer in the role of Chair by the resolution date for any reason (including but not limited to resignation, removal, or completion of term), the inquiry will resolve as NO. For the purposes of this question, any interim or acting Chair appointments will not be regarded as Powell remaining in the position.

question.title: Will Alibaba Group resolve a major workers' strike by July 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if Alibaba Group reaches an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike by July 31, 2024. For the resolution to be considered valid:

1. The strike must involve a substantial number of Alibaba Group workers (at least 1,000 participants).
2. The strike must last for at least one week.
3. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Alibaba Group and the involved union.
4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If no such resolution meeting all these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if no significant strike occurs, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will Alibaba Group settle a significant labor strike by July 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be answered with a YES if Alibaba Group comes to a consensus with the unionized employees, leading to the conclusion of a major strike by July 31, 2024. For the outcome to be deemed valid:

1. The strike must involve a considerable number of Alibaba Group employees (at least 1,000 participants).
2. The strike must persist for a minimum of one week.
3. The outcome must be validated by official announcements from both Alibaba Group and the participating union.
4. The outcome must be reported by at least two credible international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If no such resolution satisfying all these conditions is reached by the designated date, or if no major strike occurs, the question will be answered as NO.

question.title: Conditional on Alibaba Group resolving a major workers' strike, will Wisconsin hold a referendum on public school funding by July 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Alibaba Group resolves a major workers' strike by July 31, 2024. This resolution involves an agreement with unionized workers to end a strike involving at least 1,000 workers, lasting at least one week, and confirmed by official statements from both Alibaba Group and the involved union, reported by at least two reputable international news sources.

Then, is it true that Wisconsin will hold a referendum on public school funding by July 31, 2024? This referendum must be a formal, state-wide vote on a proposed constitutional amendment or legislative measure specifically addressing public school funding, verifiable through official state government announcements or reports from at least three major, reputable news organizations. If no such referendum is held by the specified date, or if a planned referendum is cancelled or postponed beyond July 31, 2024, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: If Alibaba Group successfully settles a significant workers' strike, will Wisconsin conduct a public vote on school funding by July 2024?
para_P.body:
Assuming the following condition holds: Alibaba Group successfully settles a significant workers' strike by July 31, 2024. This settlement includes an agreement with unionized workers to conclude a strike involving a minimum of 1,000 employees, lasting no less than one week, and confirmed through official statements from both Alibaba Group and the relevant union, as reported by at least two credible international news outlets.

Then, can we affirm that Wisconsin will conduct a public vote on school funding by July 31, 2024? This vote must be a formal, statewide ballot regarding a proposed constitutional amendment or legislative action specifically concerning public school funding, which can be verified through official announcements from the state government or reports from at least three major, reputable news organizations. If such a vote does not take place by the specified deadline, or if a scheduled vote is canceled or delayed past July 31, 2024, the answer will be NO.

question.title: Given Alibaba resolves a major strike and Wisconsin holds a referendum on school funding by July 2024, will the U.S. Senate cut the Pentagon's budget by over 20% by August 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: By July 31, 2024, both (a) Alibaba Group resolves a major workers' strike according to specified criteria, and (b) Wisconsin holds a referendum on public school funding as described. Then, will the U.S. Senate pass a bill by August 31, 2024, to cut the Pentagon's budget by more than 20%? 

Resolution criteria for the condition:
- For (a): Alibaba Group must reach an agreement with unionized workers, ending a significant strike involving at least 1,000 participants lasting at least one week, confirmed by official statements and reported by at least two reputable international news sources.
- For (b): Wisconsin must conduct a formal, state-wide referendum on public school funding, verifiable through official announcements or reports from at least three major news organizations.

Resolution criteria for the outcome:
- The U.S. Senate must pass a bill by August 31, 2024, that includes a reduction of more than 20% in the Pentagon's budget, confirmed by official Senate records and reported by at least two major news organizations. Mere proposals or discussions do not count; the bill must be officially passed.

para_P.title: If Alibaba successfully addresses a significant labor strike and Wisconsin conducts a public vote on education funding by July 2024, will the U.S. Senate approve a budget reduction for the Pentagon exceeding 20% by August 2024?
para_P.body:
Assuming the following holds true: By July 31, 2024, both (a) Alibaba Group successfully negotiates an agreement with union workers to resolve a major strike involving at least 1,000 participants that has lasted a minimum of one week, as confirmed by official statements and reported by at least two credible international news outlets, and (b) Wisconsin carries out a state-wide public vote on education funding, verifiable through official announcements or reports from at least three prominent news organizations. Then, will the U.S. Senate enact a law by August 31, 2024, to reduce the Pentagon's budget by more than 20%? 

Criteria for the condition's resolution:
- For (a): Alibaba Group must finalize a deal with unionized labor that ends a substantial strike lasting at least one week and involving no fewer than 1,000 workers, validated by official communications and coverage from at least two reputable international news sources.
- For (b): Wisconsin must hold a legitimate, state-wide vote regarding public school funding, which can be verified through formal announcements or reports from at least three major news organizations.

Criteria for the outcome's resolution:
- The U.S. Senate must pass legislation by August 31, 2024, that includes a budget cut of over 20% for the Pentagon, as confirmed by official Senate documentation and reported by at least two major news outlets. Simple proposals or discussions are not sufficient; the legislation must be formally enacted.

question.title: Will all of the following occur by August 2024: (1) Alibaba resolves a major workers' strike, (2) Wisconsin holds a referendum on public school funding, and (3) the U.S. Senate passes a bill to cut the Pentagon's budget by more than 20%?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if all of the following events occur by their respective deadlines:

(1) Alibaba Group reaches an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike by July 31, 2024. For the resolution to be considered valid:
   - The strike must involve at least 1,000 Alibaba Group workers.
   - The strike must last for at least one week.
   - The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Alibaba Group and the involved union.
   - The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).
   If no such resolution meeting all these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if no significant strike occurs, this part resolves as NO.

(2) The state of Wisconsin officially conducts a referendum regarding public school funding by July 31, 2024. The referendum must be a formal, state-wide vote on a proposed constitutional amendment or legislative measure specifically addressing public school funding. The occurrence of the referendum must be verifiable through official state government announcements or reports from at least three major, reputable news organizations (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, Wall Street Journal, or CNN). If no such referendum is held by the specified date, or if a planned referendum is cancelled or postponed beyond July 31, 2024, this part resolves as NO.

(3) By August 31, 2024, the United States Senate passes a bill that includes a reduction of more than 20% in the budget of the Department of Defense (Pentagon) compared to its current fiscal year's budget. The passage must be confirmed by official Senate records and reported by at least two major news organizations (e.g., Associated Press, Reuters, The New York Times, The Washington Post). If no such bill is passed by the Senate by the resolution date, or if a bill is passed but the budget cut is 20% or less, this part resolves as NO.

The question resolves as YES only if all three events occur by their respective deadlines. If any of the events do not occur, it resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will the following three events take place before August 2024: (1) Alibaba successfully negotiates an end to a significant workers' strike, (2) Wisconsin carries out a statewide vote on funding for public schools, and (3) the U.S. Senate approves legislation to reduce the Pentagon's budget by over 20%?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be deemed YES if all of these events happen by their designated deadlines:

(1) Alibaba Group comes to a settlement with its unionized employees, leading to the conclusion of a major strike by July 31, 2024. For this to be considered valid:
   - The strike must involve no fewer than 1,000 workers from Alibaba Group.
   - The strike should persist for a minimum of one week.
   - The settlement must be verified through official announcements from both Alibaba Group and the union involved.
   - The resolution must be reported by at least two credible international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).
   If such a resolution satisfying all these conditions is not reached by the specified date, or if no significant strike takes place, this component will be marked as NO.

(2) By July 31, 2024, Wisconsin is required to hold an official referendum on public school funding. This referendum must constitute a formal, statewide vote on a proposed constitutional amendment or legislative action specifically concerning public school financing. The occurrence of this referendum must be verifiable through official announcements from the state government or reports from at least three major, reputable news organizations (like Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, Wall Street Journal, or CNN). If the referendum does not occur by the specified date, or if it is canceled or postponed past July 31, 2024, this part will resolve as NO.

(3) By August 31, 2024, the United States Senate must pass a bill that entails a budget cut exceeding 20% for the Department of Defense (Pentagon) compared to the current fiscal year's budget. This passage must be confirmed by official Senate records and reported by at least two major news organizations (e.g., Associated Press, Reuters, The New York Times, The Washington Post). If such a bill is not passed by the Senate by the resolution date, or if a bill is passed but the budget reduction is 20% or less, this part will resolve as NO.

The question will be considered YES only if all three events occur by their respective deadlines. If any event does not take place, it will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will Sunny Farms be officially linked to a new salmonella outbreak by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, Sunny Farms is officially linked to a new salmonella outbreak that is different from any previously reported outbreaks. The link must be confirmed by U.S. federal health officials (such as the CDC or FDA) and reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post). The outbreak must be traced back to products from Sunny Farms and must have occurred after October 1, 2023. If no such new outbreak is linked to Sunny Farms by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will Sunny Farms be officially associated with a new salmonella outbreak by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will conclude as YES if, by July 31, 2024, Sunny Farms is officially associated with a new salmonella outbreak that is distinct from any previously documented outbreaks. The connection must be verified by U.S. federal health authorities (such as the CDC or FDA) and reported by at least two credible news organizations (e.g., Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post). The outbreak must be traced back to products from Sunny Farms and must have occurred after October 1, 2023. If no such new outbreak is connected to Sunny Farms by the resolution date, the inquiry will conclude as NO.

question.title: Conditional on Sunny Farms being officially linked to a new salmonella outbreak by July 2024, will the European Commission announce completion of a major tech data practices investigation by July 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Sunny Farms is officially linked to a new salmonella outbreak by July 31, 2024. The link must be confirmed by U.S. federal health officials (such as the CDC or FDA) and reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post). The outbreak must be traced back to products from Sunny Farms and must have occurred after October 1, 2023.

Given this, will the European Commission announce the completion of its investigation into tech data practices involving at least five major companies by July 31, 2024? Completion must be confirmed through an official European Commission announcement or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, Wall Street Journal, or New York Times). question.title: Conditional on Bloomberg Philanthropies announcing a $600 million donation to historically Black medical schools, will the Central Bank of Mexico announce an interest rate cut by August 2024?

The announcement must be confirmed by official Bank of Mexico communications, such as press releases, Governing Board statements, or public speeches by Bank officials. The interest rate in question refers to the target for the overnight interbank interest rate, which is the Central Bank of Mexico's primary tool for monetary policy.

Resolution criteria for the condition: The announcement of the donation must be made by the specified date and must be for at least $600 million, specifically for the endowments.

question.title: Conditional on the IMF announcing new funding commitments over $400 million by July 2024, will Mexican authorities declare the dismantling of Los Zetas?

question.title: Conditional on the IMF announcing over $400 million in new funding and Mexico declaring Los Zetas dismantled by July 2024, will the U.S. economy avoid a recession by July 2024?
question.body:

(b) Mexican authorities make an official public declaration stating that the Los Zetas drug cartel has been dismantled or effectively neutralized as a criminal organization. This declaration must be reported by at least two reputable international news outlets and indicate a significant disruption to the cartel's operations.

Then, is the following true: The U.S. economy does not enter a recession by July 31, 2024, where a recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis?

(c) The U.S. economy does not enter a recession. para_P.title: Are both of the following events going to take place: (1) By July 2024, will Farm Fresh Organics and Fresh Fields Inc. be officially associated with new salmonella outbreaks, and (2) will the number of fatalities from the listeria outbreak connected to smoked fish surpass 3 by August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will conclude with a YES if both of the following criteria are satisfied: (1) By July 31, 2024, both Farm Fresh Organics and Fresh Fields Inc. are officially tied to new salmonella outbreaks. Each outbreak must be distinct from any previously documented outbreaks, confirmed by U.S. federal health authorities (such as the CDC or FDA), and reported by at least two credible news outlets (e.g., Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post). The outbreaks must be traced back to products from Farm Fresh Organics and Fresh Fields Inc., respectively, and must have happened after October 1, 2023. (2) By August 31, 2024, the reported death count in the listeria outbreak associated with smoked fish must exceed 3. The death toll must be verified by official health organizations like the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) or other national health authorities. Alternatively, reports from at least three major credible news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times) citing official sources will be deemed adequate for confirmation. If either of the conditions is not fulfilled by the respective resolution dates, the question will conclude with a NO.

question.title: Will Bloomberg Philanthropies announce a $600 million donation to historically Black education schools by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Bloomberg Philanthropies officially announces a donation of $600 million to the endowments of historically Black education schools. The announcement must be confirmed by at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers) or through official statements from Bloomberg Philanthropies or the recipient institutions. The donation must be specifically intended for the endowments of these education schools. If no such announcement is made by the specified date, or if the announced amount is less than $600 million, the question resolves as NO. Note that this question is about the announcement of the donation, not its completion.

para_P.title: Will Bloomberg Philanthropies reveal a $600 million contribution to historically Black educational institutions by August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be deemed affirmative if, by August 31, 2024, Bloomberg Philanthropies publicly discloses a contribution of $600 million to the endowments of historically Black educational institutions. The disclosure must be validated by at least two credible news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers) or through official communications from Bloomberg Philanthropies or the beneficiary organizations. The contribution must be expressly designated for the endowments of these educational institutions. If no such disclosure occurs by the given date, or if the stated amount is below $600 million, the inquiry will be considered negative. It is important to note that this question pertains to the announcement of the contribution, rather than its fulfillment.

question.title: Given Bloomberg Philanthropies announces a $600 million donation to historically Black education schools by August 2024, will the DOJ announce completion of a major financial services investigation by July 2024?
question.body: Suppose the following is true: By August 31, 2024, Bloomberg Philanthropies officially announces a donation of $600 million to the endowments of historically Black education schools, confirmed by at least two reputable news sources or official statements from Bloomberg Philanthropies or the recipient institutions. The donation must be specifically intended for the endowments of these education schools. Then, will the Department of Justice (DOJ) officially announce the completion of its investigation into financial services practices involving at least five major companies by July 31, 2024, confirmed through an official DOJ announcement or reported by at least two major news outlets?

para_P.title: If Bloomberg Philanthropies declares a $600 million contribution to historically Black educational institutions by August 2024, will the DOJ reveal the conclusion of a significant investigation into financial services by July 2024?
para_P.body: Assuming the following holds true: By August 31, 2024, Bloomberg Philanthropies makes a formal announcement of a $600 million contribution to the endowments of historically Black educational institutions, validated by a minimum of two credible news outlets or official communications from Bloomberg Philanthropies or the beneficiary institutions. This contribution must be specifically designated for the endowments of these educational institutions. In that case, will the Department of Justice (DOJ) make an official statement regarding the completion of its investigation into financial services practices involving at least five major firms by July 31, 2024, as confirmed by an official DOJ statement or reported by at least two prominent news organizations?

question.title: Given Bloomberg Philanthropies announces a $600 million donation to historically Black education schools by August 2024 AND the DOJ announces completion of a major financial services investigation by July 2024, will the Central Bank of Brazil's Selic rate remain at or above 13.25% in August 2024?
question.body: Suppose the following is true: (1) By August 31, 2024, Bloomberg Philanthropies officially announces a donation of $600 million to the endowments of historically Black education schools, confirmed by at least two reputable news sources or official statements. The donation must be specifically intended for the endowments of these schools. (2) By July 31, 2024, the Department of Justice (DOJ) officially announces the completion of its investigation into financial services practices involving at least five major companies, confirmed through an official DOJ announcement or reported by at least two major news outlets. Given these conditions, will the Central Bank of Brazil's Selic rate remain at or above 13.25% in August 2024? This resolves as YES if the Selic rate is reported to be at or above 13.25% at any point during August 2024, confirmed by official Central Bank of Brazil announcements or at least two reputable financial news sources. If the rate is reported to have decreased below 13.25% and remains below this level throughout August 2024, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: If Bloomberg Philanthropies discloses a $600 million contribution to historically Black educational institutions by August 2024 AND the DOJ reveals the conclusion of a significant financial services investigation by July 2024, will the Selic rate of the Central Bank of Brazil stay at or exceed 13.25% in August 2024?
para_P.body: Assuming the following holds true: (1) By August 31, 2024, Bloomberg Philanthropies publicly declares a $600 million contribution to the endowments of historically Black educational institutions, verified by at least two credible news organizations or official announcements. This contribution must be specifically allocated for the endowments of these institutions. (2) By July 31, 2024, the Department of Justice (DOJ) publicly announces the conclusion of its investigation into financial services practices involving at least five major corporations, confirmed through an official DOJ statement or reported by at least two major news outlets. Under these circumstances, will the Selic rate of the Central Bank of Brazil remain at or above 13.25% in August 2024? This will be considered YES if the Selic rate is recorded at or above 13.25% at any time during August 2024, validated by official announcements from the Central Bank of Brazil or at least two reputable financial news sources. Conversely, if the rate is reported to have fallen below 13.25% and stays below this threshold throughout August 2024, the outcome will be NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Bloomberg Philanthropies announces a $600 million donation to historically Black education schools by August 2024 and the DOJ completes a major financial services investigation by July 2024, AND (2) the Central Bank of Brazil's Selic rate remains at or above 13.25% in August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if both of the following occur: (1) By August 31, 2024, Bloomberg Philanthropies officially announces a donation of $600 million to the endowments of historically Black education schools. The announcement must be confirmed by at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers) or through official statements from Bloomberg Philanthropies or the recipient institutions. The donation must be specifically intended for the endowments of these education schools. If no such announcement is made by the specified date, or if the announced amount is less than $600 million, this component resolves as NO. Note that this component is about the announcement of the donation, not its completion. (2) By July 31, 2024, the Department of Justice (DOJ) officially announces the completion of its investigation into financial services practices involving at least five major companies. Completion must be confirmed through an official DOJ announcement or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, Wall Street Journal, or New York Times). If the DOJ does not announce the completion of such an investigation by this date, or if the investigation is still ongoing, this component resolves as NO. The first part resolves as YES only if both components resolve as YES. (3) The Central Bank of Brazil's Selic rate is reported to be at or above 13.25% at any point during August 2024. Confirmation must come from official Central Bank of Brazil announcements or at least two reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, Folha de S.Paulo). If the rate is reported to have decreased below 13.25% and remains below this level throughout August 2024, the second part resolves as NO. The overall question resolves as YES only if both parts resolve as YES.

para_P.title: Is it true that both of the following will take place: (1) By August 2024, Bloomberg Philanthropies will declare a $600 million contribution to historically Black educational institutions and the DOJ will finalize a significant investigation into financial services by July 2024, AND (2) the Selic rate of the Central Bank of Brazil will stay at or above 13.25% in August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with YES if both of the following conditions are satisfied: (1) By the end of August 2024, Bloomberg Philanthropies officially proclaims a donation of $600 million directed towards the endowments of historically Black educational institutions. This announcement must be validated by at least two credible news organizations (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers) or through official communications from Bloomberg Philanthropies or the beneficiary institutions. The donation must specifically be aimed at the endowments of these educational entities. If no such declaration occurs by the specified deadline, or if the declared amount is less than $600 million, this part will resolve as NO. It is important to note that this part concerns the announcement of the donation, not its execution. (2) By the end of July 2024, the Department of Justice (DOJ) must officially declare that it has concluded its investigation into financial services practices involving at least five significant companies. This completion must be verified through an official DOJ announcement or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, Wall Street Journal, or New York Times). If the DOJ does not announce the conclusion of such an investigation by this date, or if the investigation remains ongoing, this part will resolve as NO. The first part can only resolve as YES if both components resolve as YES. (3) The Selic rate of the Central Bank of Brazil must be reported at or above 13.25% at any time during August 2024. Confirmation must be provided by official announcements from the Central Bank of Brazil or at least two reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, Folha de S.Paulo). If the rate is reported to have fallen below 13.25% and stays below this level throughout August 2024, the second part will resolve as NO. The overall question will resolve as YES only if both parts resolve as YES.

question.title: Will the Saudi Royal Court announce conversion of additional vehicles to biofuel by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Saudi Royal Court officially announces that additional vehicles, beyond those already known, have been converted or are in the process of being converted to run on biofuel. The announcement must come from official channels or be reported by at least two major, reputable news outlets (such as BBC, Reuters, Associated Press, or The Guardian). The additional vehicles must be part of the royal fleet or directly associated with royal transportation. If no such announcement is made by the specified date, the question will resolve as NO.

para_P.title: Will there be an announcement from the Saudi Royal Court regarding the conversion of more vehicles to biofuel by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Saudi Royal Court makes an official statement indicating that further vehicles, in addition to those already disclosed, have been converted or are undergoing conversion to biofuel. The declaration must originate from official sources or be covered by at least two major, credible news organizations (such as BBC, Reuters, Associated Press, or The Guardian). The additional vehicles should be part of the royal fleet or closely linked to royal transportation. If such an announcement is not made by the deadline, the inquiry will be answered with a NO.

question.title: Given Saudi Royal Court announces conversion of additional vehicles to biofuel by July 2024, will a major tech company relocate its headquarters to Miami by July 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: By July 31, 2024, the Saudi Royal Court officially announces that additional vehicles, beyond those already known, have been converted or are in the process of being converted to run on biofuel. This announcement must come from official channels or be reported by at least two major, reputable news outlets (such as BBC, Reuters, Associated Press, or The Guardian). The additional vehicles must be part of the royal fleet or directly associated with royal transportation.

Then, will a major tech company fully relocate its headquarters to Miami, Florida by July 31, 2024? For this to resolve as YES:
1. The relocation must be officially announced by the company or its leadership.
2. The announcement must be reported by at least two major, reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, Wall Street Journal, New York Times).
3. The new headquarters must be operational in Miami, Florida, with key executive functions transferred.

Partial relocations or plans still in progress by July 31, 2024, will not be sufficient for a YES resolution. If the move is not completed and operational by this date, or if the company decides against the move, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: With the Saudi Royal Court's announcement of additional vehicles transitioning to biofuel by July 2024, will a significant technology firm shift its headquarters to Miami by July 2024?
para_P.body:
Assuming the following is accurate: By July 31, 2024, the Saudi Royal Court formally declares that more vehicles, in addition to those previously acknowledged, have been converted or are in the midst of being converted to biofuel. This declaration must originate from official sources or be reported by at least two major, credible news organizations (such as BBC, Reuters, Associated Press, or The Guardian). The newly converted vehicles must belong to the royal fleet or be directly linked to royal transportation.

Then, will a prominent technology firm completely transfer its headquarters to Miami, Florida by July 31, 2024? For this to be considered a YES:
1. The transfer must be publicly announced by the company or its executives.
2. The announcement must be covered by at least two major, credible news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, Wall Street Journal, New York Times).
3. The new headquarters must be functional in Miami, Florida, with essential executive operations moved.

Any partial relocations or ongoing plans by July 31, 2024, will not qualify for a YES answer. If the relocation is not finalized and operational by this date, or if the company opts against the move, the question will be resolved as NO.

question.title: Given both (a) Saudi biofuel vehicle conversion and (b) Miami tech headquarters relocation by July 2024, will an enforceable ethics code for U.S. Federal Court judges be established by then?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true by July 31, 2024: (a) The Saudi Royal Court officially announces that additional vehicles have been converted to biofuel, and (b) a major tech company fully relocates its headquarters to Miami, Florida, with the new headquarters operational and key executive functions transferred. Both conditions must be confirmed by at least two major, reputable news outlets.

Then, is it true that an enforceable ethics code specifically for U.S. Federal Court judges will be established by July 31, 2024? The code must be officially adopted by the United States government, confirmed by at least two major news outlets, legally binding, and applicable to all sitting Federal Court judges, outlining clear standards of conduct and enforcement mechanisms. Mere proposals do not qualify; the code must be formally adopted and enforceable. 

If the Saudi biofuel vehicle conversion or Miami tech headquarters relocation conditions are not met, the question resolves as N/A.

para_P.title: If both (a) the conversion of vehicles to biofuel in Saudi Arabia and (b) the relocation of a technology company's headquarters to Miami occur by July 2024, will there be an established enforceable ethics code for judges in U.S. Federal Courts by that date?
para_P.body:
Assuming the following conditions hold true by July 31, 2024: (a) The Saudi Royal Court has made an official declaration regarding the conversion of additional vehicles to biofuel, and (b) a prominent technology firm has completely moved its headquarters to Miami, Florida, with the new location fully operational and key executive roles transferred. Both conditions must be validated by at least two credible and major news organizations.

Is it therefore accurate to state that an enforceable ethics code tailored for judges in U.S. Federal Courts will be in place by July 31, 2024? This code must be formally adopted by the United States government, verified by at least two major news outlets, legally binding, and applicable to all current Federal Court judges, detailing explicit conduct standards and enforcement procedures. Simple proposals will not suffice; the code must be officially approved and enforceable.

Should the conditions regarding the Saudi biofuel vehicle conversion or the Miami technology headquarters relocation not be satisfied, the question will be deemed N/A.

question.title: Will all of the following occur by July 2024: (a) the Saudi Royal Court announces conversion of additional vehicles to biofuel, (b) a major tech company fully relocates its headquarters to Miami, Florida, and (c) an enforceable ethics code for U.S. Federal Court judges is established?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if all of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024:

(a) The Saudi Royal Court officially announces that additional vehicles, beyond those already known, have been converted or are in the process of being converted to run on biofuel. The announcement must come from official channels or be reported by at least two major, reputable news outlets (such as BBC, Reuters, Associated Press, or The Guardian). The additional vehicles must be part of the royal fleet or directly associated with royal transportation.

(b) A major tech company has fully relocated its headquarters from its original location to Miami, Florida. For the resolution to be affirmative, the relocation must be officially announced by the company or its leadership, and reported by at least two major, reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, Wall Street Journal, New York Times). The new headquarters must be operational in Miami, Florida, with key executive functions transferred. Partial relocations or plans still in progress by July 31, 2024, will not be sufficient for a YES resolution.

(c) An enforceable ethics code specifically for U.S. Federal Court judges is officially adopted by the United States government. The adoption must be confirmed by at least two major, reputable news outlets (such as The New York Times, The Washington Post, Reuters, or Associated Press). The ethics code must be legally binding and applicable to all sitting Federal Court judges. It should outline clear standards of conduct and mechanisms for enforcement. If no such code meeting these criteria is established and officially adopted by the resolution date, the question will resolve as NO.

If all three of these conditions are met, the question will resolve as YES. If any of these conditions are not met, the question will resolve as NO.

para_P.title: By July 2024, will the following three events take place: (a) the Saudi Royal Court makes an announcement regarding the conversion of more vehicles to biofuel, (b) a prominent technology firm completely moves its headquarters to Miami, Florida, and (c) a legally binding ethics code for judges in U.S. Federal Courts is established?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be answered affirmatively (YES) if all of the subsequent conditions are fulfilled by July 31, 2024:

(a) The Saudi Royal Court publicly declares that additional vehicles, beyond those already acknowledged, have been converted or are in the process of being converted to biofuel. This declaration must come from official sources or be reported by at least two major, reputable news organizations (such as BBC, Reuters, Associated Press, or The Guardian). The newly converted vehicles must be part of the royal fleet or directly linked to royal transportation.

(b) A significant technology company has entirely shifted its headquarters from its original site to Miami, Florida. For the resolution to be YES, this relocation must be officially announced by the company or its executives and reported by at least two major, reputable news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, Wall Street Journal, New York Times). The new headquarters must be fully operational in Miami, Florida, with essential executive functions moved. Any partial relocations or plans still underway by July 31, 2024, will not suffice for a YES resolution.

(c) An enforceable ethics code specifically for judges of U.S. Federal Courts is officially enacted by the United States government. This enactment must be verified by at least two major, reputable news sources (such as The New York Times, The Washington Post, Reuters, or Associated Press). The ethics code must be legally binding and applicable to all current Federal Court judges, outlining clear standards of conduct and enforcement mechanisms. If no such code that meets these requirements is established and officially enacted by the resolution date, the inquiry will resolve as NO.

If all three of these conditions are satisfied, the question will resolve as YES. If any of these conditions are unmet, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will Fisker receive over $500 million in grants for electric vehicle initiatives by July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, Fisker is confirmed to have received more than $500 million in grants from the U.S. federal government for electric vehicle-related initiatives. These initiatives may include manufacturing, assembly, or other aspects of electric vehicle production. The confirmation must come from official government announcements, Fisker's official statements, or reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, Wall Street Journal, New York Times). The grants must be specifically allocated for electric vehicle-related projects and not for general automotive purposes. If no such confirmation is made by the specified date, or if the confirmed amount is $500 million or less, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Is it expected that Fisker will obtain more than $500 million in federal grants for electric vehicle projects by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be considered YES if, by July 31, 2024, it is verified that Fisker has received in excess of $500 million in grants from the U.S. federal government specifically for initiatives related to electric vehicles. These initiatives could encompass manufacturing, assembly, or other facets of electric vehicle production. Verification must be provided through official government announcements, statements from Fisker, or coverage by at least three prominent news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, Wall Street Journal, or New York Times). The funds must be designated for electric vehicle initiatives and not for general automotive uses. If no confirmation is available by the designated date, or if the verified amount is $500 million or less, the inquiry will resolve as NO.

question.title: Given Fisker receives over $500 million in grants for electric vehicle initiatives by July 2024, will the Central Bank of Russia announce a reduction in its key interest rate by August 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: By July 31, 2024, Fisker is confirmed to have received more than $500 million in grants from the U.S. federal government for electric vehicle-related initiatives. These initiatives may include manufacturing, assembly, or other aspects of electric vehicle production. The confirmation must come from official government announcements, Fisker's official statements, or reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, Wall Street Journal, New York Times). The grants must be specifically allocated for electric vehicle-related projects and not for general automotive purposes.

Then, will the Central Bank of Russia publicly announce a reduction in its key interest rate by August 31, 2024? The announcement must be officially made by the Central Bank of Russia and reported by at least two reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC. The reduction must be in the key rate, which is the Central Bank of Russia's primary tool for influencing the economy. A mere hint or speculation about future rate cuts does not qualify; there must be a concrete announcement of an actual rate reduction.

para_P.title: If Fisker secures more than $500 million in funding for electric vehicle projects by July 2024, will the Central Bank of Russia declare a cut in its main interest rate by August 2024?
para_P.body:
Assuming the following holds true: By July 31, 2024, it is verified that Fisker has obtained over $500 million in funding from the federal government of the United States for projects related to electric vehicles. These projects could involve manufacturing, assembly, or other facets of electric vehicle production. The verification must come from official government announcements, statements from Fisker, or coverage by at least three major news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, Wall Street Journal, New York Times). The funding must be earmarked specifically for electric vehicle-related endeavors and not for general automotive purposes.

Then, will the Central Bank of Russia officially declare a reduction in its main interest rate by August 31, 2024? The announcement must be made by the Central Bank of Russia and reported by at least two credible financial news outlets such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC. The reduction must pertain to the key interest rate, which serves as the Central Bank of Russia's primary mechanism for economic influence. A simple suggestion or speculation regarding potential future rate cuts does not meet the criteria; there must be a definitive announcement of an actual rate decrease.

question.title: Conditional on Fisker receiving over $500 million in grants for electric vehicle initiatives by July 2024 and the Central Bank of Russia announcing a reduction in its key interest rate by August 2024, will Swiss banking employees remain on strike through August 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: By July 31, 2024, Fisker receives more than $500 million in grants from the U.S. federal government specifically for electric vehicle-related initiatives, confirmed by official government announcements, Fisker's official statements, or reports from at least three major news organizations. Additionally, by August 31, 2024, the Central Bank of Russia publicly announces a reduction in its key interest rate, reported by at least two reputable financial news sources. Given these conditions, will Swiss banking employees remain on strike through August 2024?

Resolution criteria: Resolves YES if, by August 31, 2024, banking employees in Switzerland are still on strike or have not fully resumed normal operations following any current labor dispute. The status of the strike or work resumption must be confirmed by official statements from the banks, the unions representing the workers, or the Swiss government, and reported by at least two reputable news sources. If the employees have fully returned to work and normal operations have resumed before or during August 2024, the question resolves as NO. Partial returns to work or limited operations do not count as a full resolution of the strike.

para_P.title: If Fisker secures more than $500 million in funding for electric vehicle projects by July 2024 and the Central Bank of Russia declares a decrease in its primary interest rate by August 2024, will the employees of Swiss banks continue their strike until the end of August 2024?
para_P.body:
Assuming the following holds true: By July 31, 2024, Fisker has obtained over $500 million in funding from the U.S. federal government explicitly for initiatives related to electric vehicles, as verified by official government announcements, statements from Fisker, or reports from at least three major news outlets. Furthermore, by August 31, 2024, the Central Bank of Russia publicly reveals a cut in its key interest rate, as reported by at least two credible financial news organizations. Under these circumstances, will the employees of Swiss banks persist in their strike throughout August 2024?

Criteria for resolution: This will be marked as YES if, by August 31, 2024, banking employees in Switzerland are still on strike or have not completely resumed regular operations following any ongoing labor disputes. The situation regarding the strike or the resumption of work must be verified by official announcements from the banks, the unions representing the employees, or the Swiss government, and reported by at least two trustworthy news sources. If the employees have completely returned to work and normal operations have resumed prior to or during August 2024, the outcome will be NO. Any partial returns to work or limited operations do not qualify as a full resolution of the strike.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Fisker receives over $500 million in grants for electric vehicle initiatives by July 2024 and the Central Bank of Russia announces a reduction in its key interest rate by August 2024, (2) Swiss banking employees remain on strike through August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES only if both of the following occur: (1) By July 31, 2024, Fisker is confirmed to have received more than $500 million in grants from the U.S. federal government specifically for electric vehicle-related initiatives, with confirmation from official government announcements, Fisker's official statements, or reports from at least three major news organizations. Additionally, by August 31, 2024, the Central Bank of Russia publicly announces a reduction in its key interest rate, with the announcement reported by at least two reputable financial news sources. (2) By August 31, 2024, banking employees in Switzerland are still on strike or have not fully resumed normal operations following any current labor dispute. The status of the strike or work resumption must be confirmed by official statements from the banks, the unions representing the workers, or the Swiss government, and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Swissinfo, Neue Zürcher Zeitung, or Reuters). Both conditions in (1) and the condition in (2) must be met for the question to resolve as YES; if any condition is not met, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Are the following two events going to happen: (1) Fisker will obtain more than $500 million in funding for electric vehicle projects by July 2024, while the Central Bank of Russia will declare a decrease in its main interest rate by August 2024, and (2) banking staff in Switzerland will continue their strike until August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES only if both of the subsequent events take place: (1) By July 31, 2024, it is confirmed that Fisker has received in excess of $500 million in funding from the U.S. federal government specifically allocated for electric vehicle projects, with validation from official government announcements, statements from Fisker, or reports from at least three major news outlets. Furthermore, by August 31, 2024, the Central Bank of Russia must publicly declare a reduction in its key interest rate, with the announcement covered by at least two credible financial news organizations. (2) By August 31, 2024, banking employees in Switzerland must still be on strike or have not completely returned to regular operations following any ongoing labor dispute. The status of the strike or return to work must be validated by official statements from the banks, the unions representing the workers, or the Swiss government, and reported by at least two reliable news sources (such as Swissinfo, Neue Zürcher Zeitung, or Reuters). Both conditions in (1) and the condition in (2) must be fulfilled for the inquiry to be answered as YES; if any condition is not fulfilled, the inquiry will be answered as NO.

question.title: Will the ICC officially announce plans to use AI for umpire decision reviews by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the International Cricket Council (ICC) officially announces a plan to use AI technology for reviewing umpire decisions in cricket matches. The announcement must come from an official ICC source, such as a press release, official statement, or announcement during an ICC event. The plan should specifically state the intention to implement AI technology for umpire decision reviews. The announcement must be reported by at least two major sports news outlets (e.g., ESPN, ICC-cricket.com, Cricbuzz, The Guardian). If no such announcement is made by the resolution date, or if the ICC only announces continued testing or partial implementation without a clear plan to fully implement the technology, the question will resolve as NO.

para_P.title: Will the ICC make an official declaration regarding the use of AI for umpire decision reviews by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be deemed affirmative if, by July 31, 2024, the International Cricket Council (ICC) makes an official declaration about utilizing AI technology to review umpire decisions in cricket matches. The declaration must originate from an official ICC channel, such as a press release, formal statement, or announcement at an ICC event. The statement should explicitly mention the intention to adopt AI technology for umpire decision reviews. This announcement must be covered by at least two prominent sports news organizations (e.g., ESPN, ICC-cricket.com, Cricbuzz, The Guardian). If no such declaration occurs by the resolution date, or if the ICC only announces ongoing testing or partial implementation without a definitive plan for full adoption of the technology, the inquiry will be resolved as negative.

question.title: Conditional on the ICC announcing plans to use AI for umpire decision reviews by July 2024, will Stellantis' quarterly net income increase by over 20% year-over-year by then?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: By July 31, 2024, the International Cricket Council (ICC) officially announces a plan to use AI technology for reviewing umpire decisions in cricket matches. The announcement must come from an official ICC source, such as a press release, official statement, or announcement during an ICC event, and it must be reported by at least two major sports news outlets (e.g., ESPN, ICC-cricket.com, Cricbuzz, The Guardian).

Given this, will Stellantis report a net income increase of more than 20% for any quarter compared to the same quarter in the previous year, in its official financial statements released by July 31, 2024? The increase must be verified through official company earnings reports or at least three credible financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, Wall Street Journal). If no such increase is reported by the resolution date, or if the highest reported increase is 20% or less, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: If the ICC reveals intentions to implement AI for umpire decision reviews by July 2024, will Stellantis' quarterly net earnings rise by over 20% year-on-year by that time?
para_P.body:
Assume the following holds true: By July 31, 2024, the International Cricket Council (ICC) makes an official announcement regarding the use of AI technology for reviewing umpire decisions in cricket matches. This announcement must originate from a legitimate ICC source, such as a press release, formal statement, or declaration during an ICC event, and must be covered by at least two prominent sports news outlets (e.g., ESPN, ICC-cricket.com, Cricbuzz, The Guardian).

In light of this, will Stellantis disclose a net income growth exceeding 20% for any quarter in comparison to the same quarter from the previous year, in its official financial disclosures published by July 31, 2024? The increase must be substantiated through official company earnings reports or at least three reputable financial news organizations (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, Wall Street Journal). If no such growth is documented by the resolution date, or if the maximum reported growth is 20% or lower, the answer will be NO.

question.title: Given both AI plans by ICC and Stellantis' income rise, will Mariko Silver be Met Museum president in August 2024?

(a) The ICC's announcement must come from an official ICC source and be reported by at least two major sports news outlets, stating the intention to implement AI technology for umpire decision reviews.
(b) Stellantis must report a net income increase of more than 20% for any quarter compared to the same quarter in the previous year, verified through official company earnings reports or at least three credible financial news sources.

Resolution criteria for the outcome: Mariko Silver must hold the position of president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in August 2024, confirmed by official announcements by the museum or at least two reputable news sources. If she resigns, is replaced, or otherwise leaves the position before or during August 2024, or if the museum announces plans for her departure effective before or during August 2024, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will the European Commission implement a significant tariff on Chinese-made solar panels by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, the European Commission officially implements a tariff of 50% or higher on imports of Chinese-made solar panels. The implementation must be confirmed by official European Commission announcements and reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, Financial Times, or The Economist). The tariff must be specifically targeted at solar panels manufactured in China and not part of a broader tariff on all Chinese goods or all electronic goods. If no such tariff meeting these criteria is implemented by the specified date, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will there be a major duty imposed by the European Commission on solar panels produced in China by August 2024?

The duty must be specifically aimed at solar panels made in China and not part of a wider duty affecting all Chinese products or all electronic items. question.title: Will Google's AI assistant be reported for spreading election misinformation by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, there are credible reports or official warnings from election officials, government authorities, or reputable news organizations stating that Google's AI assistant is spreading election misinformation. For the purpose of this question, 'election misinformation' refers to false or misleading information about election processes, candidates, or results. Credible reports should come from at least two of the following sources: state or federal election officials, major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, BBC, or major US networks), or peer-reviewed studies published in reputable journals. The reports or warnings must specifically mention the AI assistant and its role in spreading election misinformation. If no such reports or warnings are issued by the resolution date, the question will resolve as NO.

para_P.title: By August 2024, will there be reports about Google's AI assistant disseminating false information regarding elections?

Credible accounts must originate from at least two of the following sources: state or federal election officials, prominent media organizations (such as Associated Press, Reuters, BBC, or major US television networks), or peer-reviewed research published in respected journals. question.title: Given Google's AI assistant is reported for spreading election misinformation by August 2024, will Texas hold a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: By August 31, 2024, there are credible reports or official warnings from election officials, government authorities, or reputable news organizations stating that Google's AI assistant is spreading election misinformation. For the purpose of this question, 'election misinformation' refers to false or misleading information about election processes, candidates, or results. Credible reports should come from at least two of the following sources: state or federal election officials, major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, BBC, or major US networks), or peer-reviewed studies published in reputable journals. The reports or warnings must specifically mention the AI assistant and its role in spreading election misinformation.

Then, will the following be true: Texas officially conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state by August 31, 2024? For a positive resolution:

1. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the Texas state government.
2. The referendum must explicitly address the issue of abortion rights protection.
3. The results of the referendum must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

The question will resolve as NO if:

1. No such referendum occurs by August 31, 2024.
2. A planned referendum is cancelled or postponed beyond the specified date.
3. A referendum is held, but it does not specifically focus on enshrining protection for abortion rights.

Note: This question does not consider the outcome of the referendum, only whether it takes place within the specified timeframe.

Then, will it be true that Texas officially holds a public vote aimed at establishing protections for abortion rights within the state by August 31, 2024? For a positive answer:

2. The public vote must clearly address the matter of safeguarding abortion rights.

The question will be resolved as NO if:

1. No such public vote occurs by August 31, 2024.

Note: This inquiry does not take into account the result of the public vote, only whether it is conducted within the given timeframe.

question.title: Will the NFL officially announce plans to use AI for game strategy analysis by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the National Football League (NFL) officially announces a plan to use AI technology for analyzing game strategies. The plan should specifically state the intention to implement AI technology for game strategy analysis. The announcement must be reported by at least two major sports news outlets (e.g., ESPN, NFL.com, Sports Illustrated, The Athletic). question.title: Conditional on the NFL announcing plans to use AI for game strategy analysis by July 2024, will Norwegian oil workers remain on strike through August 2024?

The plan should specifically state the intention to implement AI technology for game strategy analysis. Given this, is it true that by August 31, 2024, oil workers in Norway are still on strike or have not fully resumed normal operations following any current labor dispute? The status of the strike or work resumption must be confirmed by official statements from oil companies, the unions representing the workers, or the Norwegian government, and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as NRK, Aftenposten, or Reuters). Verification will be based on official index reports from reputable financial market data providers such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or the Johannesburg Stock Exchange. question.title: Conditional on Kamala Harris announcing her running mate at a rally in Minneapolis by August 2024, will Justin Trudeau remain the Prime Minister of Canada through July 2024?
question.body:

This resolves as YES if Justin Trudeau continues to hold the position of Prime Minister of Canada through July 31, 2024, with confirmation from official Canadian government records or credible news reports from at least two major news organizations (e.g., CBC, The Globe and Mail, Reuters, AFP). The question resolves as NO if Trudeau leaves or is removed from the position at any point before or during July 2024. Temporary absences due to illness or vacation do not count as leaving the position.

question.title: Given Amazon announces additional layoffs and Rogers Communications confirms a hacker payment, will Italy's Senate pass an economic reform bill opposed by PM Meloni by August 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true:

1. Amazon officially announces further layoffs beyond the initially reported 5% of its workforce by August 31, 2024. This announcement must be confirmed through official company statements or reports from at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). 2. Rogers Communications publicly confirms through an official statement or press release that they made a payment to a hacker to erase sensitive data by July 31, 2024. This confirmation must be reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or The New York Times). The payment must be specifically for erasing sensitive data.

Then, will Italy's Senate pass a major economic reform bill that is explicitly opposed by Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni or her administration by August 31, 2024? The bill must be related to economic policy, such as fiscal spending, taxation, or monetary policy, and must be passed by the Senate, regardless of whether it becomes law. The opposition from Prime Minister Meloni or her administration must be clearly reported by at least two major international news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, Financial Times). The bill must be described as 'major' or 'significant' by these news sources in terms of its potential impact on the Italian economy.

para_P.title: If Amazon reveals further job cuts and Rogers Communications admits to paying off a hacker, will the Italian Senate approve an economic reform proposal that Prime Minister Meloni opposes by August 2024?
para_P.body:
